channel.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
channel.description:
I2P packages are available in buster, so why do we have manual download steps on the I2P wiki page?
https://packages.debian.org/buster/i2p https://packages.debian.org/buster/i2pd
Does package availability help to solve this?
http://forums.dds6qkxpwdeubwucdiaord2xgbbeyds25rbsgr73tbfpqpt4a6vjwsyd.onion/t/i2p-integration/4981
And presumably issue of "Installing I2P on Whonix-Gateway ‚Ñ¢ (I2P and Tor simultaneously)"

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: HulaHoop
item.description:
Go ahead and deprecate. No point keeping an automated script around if the mechanism it depends on is unreliable and unsupported.

Read full topic

item.description:
Patrick:

There is i2pbrowser but nobody maintaining it.

And because of Tor Browser Customization using user.js (for example for i2pbrowser) it‚Äôs unlikely to ever get fixed. Hence, I plan to remove Any veto? @HulaHoop

  • i2p packages installed by default in Whonix-Workstation: yes/no

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Thinkablemellow via Whonix Forum:

Patrick:

There are various aspects to security. If Tor can be revoked, do we
care? Yes. But is it strictly what most means when talking about
security generally? Not sure.

Connection security: Yes, we‚Äôd miss out some. But do we care? We don‚Äôt
trust i2p to keep users anonymous. We use Tor for that. Therefore it‚Äôs
not of critical importance.

I disagree,
thats a wicked sense of security, using old version should be a problem no matter what the changelog says.

Welcome to Debian stable where all versions are frozen until the next
major release.

How would you handle this Mess if there were any RCE found in the old releases ?

Debian fixes RCE‚Äôs in Debian stable.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Thinkablemellow
item.description:
Patrick:

There are various aspects to security. If Tor can be revoked, do we
care? Yes. But is it strictly what most means when talking about
security generally? Not sure.

Connection security: Yes, we‚Äôd miss out some. But do we care? We don‚Äôt
trust i2p to keep users anonymous. We use Tor for that. Therefore it‚Äôs
not of critical importance.

I disagree,
thats a wicked sense of security, using old version should be a problem no matter what the changelog says.
We lose compatility to plugins and propably a lot more that we aren‚Äôt aware of.
I2P trough Tor is discouraged by I2P‚Äôs devs and adding a old Version on top makes all this a waste of both Ressources (I2P‚Äôs and Tor‚Äôs)

How would you handle this Mess if there were any RCE found in the old releases ?

I dont see any reason to continue this under these Views.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
TNT_BOM_BOM via Whonix Forum:

Which features/fixes would the i2p Debian package lack that are only
available from i2p upstream?

Tons of bug fixes which making the software more secure plus stable on
the connection level (check the release notes of each release from
debian release version up to upstream version)

I finished reading the changelog between the Debian buster version
0.9.38 and latest upstream i2p 0.9.45.

There are various aspects to security. If Tor can be revoked, do we
care? Yes. But is it strictly what most means when talking about
security generally? Not sure.

Connection security: Yes, we‚Äôd miss out some. But do we care? We don‚Äôt
trust i2p to keep users anonymous. We use Tor for that. Therefore it‚Äôs
not of critical importance.

Remote exploitable security issues fixed between 0.9.38 and 0.9.45: none.

Is the i2p Debian package really so bad that we‚Äôre better off not
installing it by default in Whonix-Workstation?

Yes, there is no even maintainer for I2P on debian sid.(mhatta
disappeared since long time)

Debian sid has i2p 0.9.44

i2p upstream has i2p 0.9.45 released 2020-02-25.

If he disappeared, that‚Äôs a problem indeed.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Back to i2p pre-installation discussion.

Why Debian package doesn‚Äôt auto update itself: previously answered by me in this thread (Debian never does this; would conflict with upgrades from packages.debian.org).

Which features/fixes would the i2p Debian package lack that are only available from i2p upstream?

Is the i2p Debian package really so bad that we‚Äôre better off not installing it by default in Whonix-Workstation?

HulaHoop:

eyedeekay is busy (life happens to all of us) and has said he won‚Äôt have time to dedicate to these projects. Without official support by I2P upstream the status and viability of this project is uncertain. Building around uncertain software tends to be a waste of time as we end up having to tear it out and remove all the documentation written for it.

Yes, that back and forth only doesn‚Äôt matter if time is unlimited which it is not.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: HulaHoop
item.description:
Thinkablemellow:

Why the uncertainty ?

eyedeekay is busy (life happens to all of us) and has said he won‚Äôt have time to dedicate to these projects. Without official support by I2P upstream the status and viability of this project is uncertain. Building around uncertain software tends to be a waste of time as we end up having to tear it out and remove all the documentation written for it.

Thinkablemellow:

If it doesnt hurt why wouldn‚Äôt we want to use it ?

We can‚Äôt maintain it and it depends a lot more on browser changes than the current pref solution.

Thinkablemellow:

It could be removed when support ceases and all else keeps on working. We dont need to choose, we can add it if it works and remove it when it stops.

It doesn‚Äôt work ATM so this is a moot point, however I wrote the above in case it were a choice today.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
Thinkablemellow:

Just tested i2pbrowser with the addon and it works if the Setting browser.privatebrowsing.autostart=false is set.

not good. plugin need to work while this option is on otherwise not worthy for TB.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Thinkablemellow
item.description:
HulaHoop:

The add on looks interesting no doubt, but given the uncertainty of future maintenance, I am wary of switching to it even if it supported TBB

Why the uncertainty ?
If it doesnt hurt why wouldn‚Äôt we want to use it ?
It could be removed when support ceases and all else keeps on working. We dont need to choose, we can add it if it works and remove it when it stops.

HulaHoop:

The current i2pbrowser implementation enables arbitrary localhost software proxy support and I don‚Äôt know if the addon will give us that.

I‚Äôll ask idk(eyedeekay) about that.

Looking at the TODO stuff he got plenty in the pipeline and a lot of useful feature we could use in the Future.
So it would be a waste not to use it or at least prepare for it.

But i‚Äôm not the one to decide this‚Ä¶

Edit:
Just tested i2pbrowser with the addon and it works if the Setting browser.privatebrowsing.autostart=false is set.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: HulaHoop
item.description:
The extension is designed to work with Firefox and likely has a hard time modifying TBB where it is patched and a bunch of functionality in vanilla is locked down.

The add on looks interesting no doubt, but given the uncertainty of future maintenance, I am wary of switching to it even if it supported TBB. The current i2pbrowser implementation is simpler to understand and maintain for us simpletons who don‚Äôt develop browser stuff. With added functionality, more is likely to break and we won‚Äôt know how to fix it. The current i2pbrowser implementation enables arbitrary localhost software proxy support and I don‚Äôt know if the addon will give us that.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Thinkablemellow
item.description:
Thinkablemellow:

Yes it is, it also works with the debian i2p

Scratch that, it isnt working with TBB, it doesnt change color in any tab, it isnt redirecting etc.
Not sure why, i2pbrowser ‚Äúworks‚Äù but only due to our changes not the addon and it has no effect.
I guess it has something to do with containers?

Firefox works without an issue in the WS with our current Setup and the Addon.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Thinkablemellow:

But why would we want to use it ?

Did not use it myself yet but features sound amazing.

Quote https://eyedeekay.github.io/I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox/

Selection of features that sound useful even in combination with Whonix:

  • [done] Provide a way to launch into an I2P-Specific contextual identity (container). Intercept requests to .i2p domains and automatically route them to the I2P container. Isolate the router console from other local applications by automatically intercepting requests to the router console to another container.
  • [done] Indicate the I2P browser is in use visually.
  • [done] Change the color of the browser window to indicate that I2P is in use
  • [done] Set the http proxy to use the local I2P proxy automatically. Provide specific configuration for other types of I2P proxies(SOCKS, isolating HTTP)
  • [done] Monitor the health and readiness of the I2P router it is instructed to use. Currently the plugin checks whether the HTTP Proxy is working by fetching an image from ‚Äúhttp://proxy.i2p‚Äù and displaying a result. A work-in-progress binding to i2pcontrol is available in ./i2pcontrol, it is inert at this time.
  • [Done] Handle router console applications under their own origins and within their own contextual identity. (1) The router console is automatically confined to it‚Äôs own container tab. (2) Use a custom protocol handler to place each i2p application/plugin under it‚Äôs own origin, shortening router console URL‚Äôs and placing applications under their own origin.
  • [Done] Handle Torrents by talking to i2psnark-rpc plugin and then adding them directly into the Firefox downloads drop-downs, menus, etc. If I can.

Read full topic
item.source: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Thinkablemellow
item.description:
‚ÄúNot sure if a useful question to ask but is I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox compatible with Tor Browser?‚Äù

(Cant reply on Git)
Yes it is, it also works with the debian i2p

But why would we want to use it ?
The only reason i see is the color change in TBB when browsing i2p.All else is already working, so why add more ‚Äúmoving Parts‚Äù?

Read full topic

Please follow this discussion:

It‚Äôs related to I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox:

GitHub

eyedeekay/I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox

I2P in Private Browsing mode for Firefox, built using Webextensions and Contextual Identities - eyedeekay/I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox

https://eyedeekay.github.io/I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox/

addons.mozilla.org

I2P In Private Browsing ‚Äì Get this Extension for ü¶ä Firefox (en-US)

Download I2P In Private Browsing for Firefox. Uses Container Tabs to set up a browser to use I2P conveniently and safely by setting up an I2P-powered Private Browsing mode, inspired by the similar feature in Brave.

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Patrick_mobile
item.description:
No need. Debian always disables internal updaters. For any package. Its Debian stable vision of freezing software versions. Otherwise internal updater would conflict with Debian package upgrades.

item.title: Installation and Fix of i2p inside Whonix-Workstation by Default
item.dc:creator: Thinkablemellow
item.description:
Patrick:

Why /home why not ‚Äúnothing‚Äù? Would ‚Äúplain‚Äù http://127.0.0.1:7657 be
better?

127.0.0.1:7657 is of little use , /home shows the Bookmark links and the hompage of the console from i2p.
There is also a bug, the First run Wizard is shown when opening 127.0.0.1:7657 for the first time (could be due to the Outdated version as i‚Äôm unable to reproduce that in a normal Debian VM or in I2Pbrowser(from I2P)

Is there any way/config to change the color of the Menubar or Urlbar so people know that they use I2Pbrowser and not TBB, similar to what eyedeekay is doing with https://github.com/eyedeekay/I2P-in-Private-Browsing-Mode-Firefox but without the need of a addon?

Also can we replace that custom Homepage to a fork of Whonix TBB Homepage with I2P links and the Notes the current i2p one has?
If so what Whonix Links should stay (if any)?
I already made a fork but i rather ask before continuing.

@HulaHoop

HulaHoop:

The static I2P version in stable is not set in stone. We can revert the auto updater disabling they‚Äôve done in Debian, but I want to know the Debian devs‚Äô reason for doing it in the first place.

I would guess its some kind of Debian Policy ? But i‚Äôm too unfamiliar with Debian and their process.
I thought it was set by I2P‚Äôs Devs because of that.

HulaHoop:

@Thinkablemellow @TNT_BOM_BOM can you get in touch with the Debian devs and ask them why they‚Äôve turned the updater off?

Create an Issue on their Tracker or where to ask?

Read full topic
